moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6
comment: Though he has occasionally played this before it's somewhat interesting because usually plays 2...Nc6, often heading for the Marshall Gambit of the Spanish Game.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6
comment: Essentially Black says White will have an isolated queen's pawn and Black will develop easily and then attempt to exploit his pawn structure advantages  (White's disadvantages) .

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3
comment: White is anticipating having an isolated queen's pawn and wants to avoid ...Bc8-g4xf3, undermining Pd4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4
comment: Finally Black feels it's safe, or necessary, to get rid of Pc4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6
comment: After this it's clear Black's plan is to occupy square d5, trade off White's light square bishop, occupy the central files with rooks and pressure Pd4. White has used h2-h3 to prevent ...Bc8-g4xf3, but Pd4 will be a weakness for some time. White, on the other hand, has use of Pd4 and the control of e5 it provides. Black's most dangerous piece is the one which can attack Pd4, so Bc1-g5, aiming to trade for Be7, might be very good. Perhaps White should encourage Black to occupy d5 (a2-a3 Nb4-d5) with a minor piece, so the file won't be open and Pd4 might be more safe. Then White could focus on occupying and utilizing the e-file.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3
comment: It doesn't seem to me the queen does well here; it competes with Bc4 for light squares. The idea is to combine pressure on d5 with the threat to Be7. If Black has to use Qd5 to defend d5 then what defends Be7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5
comment: Now neither side has perfect pawns, but Pd5 might possibly be the weakest. At least Black has kept the e-file closed, so Re1 isn't terribly useful  (yet) .

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6
comment: further ruining Black's pawns and giving Bc4 room to retreat to b3, continuing the threat to Pd5

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3
comment: The c-file is now open, but there's no way for Black to invade at c2 (Bb3 controls c2) . On the other hand, White might try to invade to c7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8
comment: Black's pieces seem to have everything covered except e5. Next he has to figure out how to exchange pieces to lead to an equal endgame. White will avoid most exchanges, but how can he make progress? I suppose f2-f4-f5 is one way of disturbing the coordination of Black's position.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5
comment: This appears to be chasing Bf4 toward a less useful square, but it might also serve to prevent f2-f4-f5. Unfortunately, for Black, it also shows up later as a weak point, not easily supported by pieces.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1
comment: White has apparently decided he still has more chance for success via the e-file than anywhere else. How is he going to move Be6 off the file?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7
comment: This seems odd to me. Of course, White doesn't have time for f2-f3 because ...Bxd4 is check, giving Black time to retreat ...Ne4-f6. But, it probably leads to a trade of dark-square bishops, something Black has been avoiding.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5
comment: I don't see what Black gains by this exchange.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8
comment: Can't anyone see why White is continuing to try to win, isn't it obvious he has tremendous potential? How can a Grandmaster achieve victories when he begins with this kind of position? Even Fischer, known for squeezing out points from such positions, had great difficulty against the better defenders of his day, such as Petrosian.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6
comment: a slightly awkward place for the rook

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4
comment: Pg5 is hard for Black to support and White can simply push through over there, aiming eventually for g4-g5 to kick Nf6 away from the defense of Pd5. I know that may seem odd, since there are pawns in the way, but if Pg5 has to give way after h3-h4xg5 and f3-f4xg5, then White will indeed be able to put a pawn at g5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4 Bb5 34. Re5 gxh4+ 35. Kxh4 Bc4
comment: In a general sense every one of Black's pawns is bad, but his pieces are wel placed to complement them. It's not so easy for White to make inroads.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4 Bb5 34. Re5 gxh4+ 35. Kxh4 Bc4 36. Bc2
comment: White can try to chase Bc4 by playing a2-a4 (cutting off one retreat square) and then b2-b3. Bc4 is well placed, but can be chased to a horrible a6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4 Bb5 34. Re5 gxh4+ 35. Kxh4 Bc4 36. Bc2 Bb5
comment: If White chases it now with a2-a4 the bishop retreats on the b5-e8 diagonal and Pa4 is suddenly a target! Incidentally, Black might now threaten ...Rc7-c4, hitting Nb4 and Pd4.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4 Bb5 34. Re5 gxh4+ 35. Kxh4 Bc4 36. Bc2 Bb5 37. a3 Rd8 38. Kg3 Kg7 39. Bf5 Kf8 40. Rh1 Kg7 41. Nc2
comment: White is making a definite shift toward the king-side. I suppose he feels more confident of achieving something after g4-g5 and he wants to attack Black's king. Whether Black just exchanges pawns, opening the h- and g-files, or moves Nf6, there will be some room for White's pieces in that area. Black's rooks have to react somehow to oppose White's rooks.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nxe5 d6 4. Nf3 Nxe4 5. d4 d5 6. Bd3 Nc6 7. O-O Be7 8. c4 Nf6 9. h3 O-O 10. Nc3 Nb4 11. Be2 dxc4 12. Bxc4 c6 13. Bg5 Nbd5 14. Re1 Be6 15. Qb3 Qb6 16. Nxd5 cxd5 17. Qxb6 axb6 18. Bb3 h6 19. Bf4 Rfc8 20. Ne5 g5 21. Bh2 Bb4 22. Re2 Ne4 23. Nd3 Bf8 24. Rae1 Bg7 25. Be5 Bxe5 26. Nxe5 Kg7 27. Nd3 Rc7 28. Nb4 Rd8 29. g4 Nf6 30. Kg2 Rd6 31. f3 Bd7 32. Kg3 Kf8 33. h4 Bb5 34. Re5 gxh4+ 35. Kxh4 Bc4 36. Bc2 Bb5 37. a3 Rd8 38. Kg3 Kg7 39. Bf5 Kf8 40. Rh1 Kg7 41. Nc2 Re8 42. Ne3 Rce7 43. Kf4 Bc6 44. Bc2 Bd7 45. g5
comment: White's dominance of the dark squares should remind Black of why he traded dark-square bishops, weakening his control of e5.
